name: 2,3-DIMETHYL-PARA-ANISALDEHYDE
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4003
Reason: The compound 2,3-Dimethyl-para-anisaldehyde consists of a benzene ring (basic unit) with added substituents that influence the melting point. Benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. Each methyl group typically raises the melting point due to increased molecular weight and slightly larger van der Waals forces, estimated as +5°C per methyl group. Methoxy (-OCH3) group, being an electron-donating group and having larger molecular volume than hydrogen, generally increases the melting point; estimated effect is +15°C for methoxy. Aldehyde (-CHO) group generally has a dipole and can form weak hydrogen bonds with other molecules, leading to an increase in melting point as well; estimated increase is +12°C. Combining these contributions results in an estimated melting point change.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, anisaldehyde has a melting point of around 40°C. 
- Methyl groups: Each methyl group is expected to increase the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The effect of a methyl group on the melting point can be estimated to be around +5°C per methyl group. 
- The presence of two methyl groups on the para position (2,3-di) is expected to have a cumulative effect on the melting point.
##Prediction: 55.0
